Award.AwardTitle: AIS: Collaborative Research: A Novel Intelligent Grid Optimization Architecture Using Hierarchical Multi-Agent Framework for Modern Sustainable Power Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a high-performance novel and intelligent grid optimization architecture which is distributed (low-cost) and that balances supply and demand in real-time over multiple levels of the electric power grid. The approach is to link power flow optimization routines across a three-layer hierarchy of power grid: circuits, substations, and the transmission grid using the proposed integrated Approximate Dynamic Programming and Dynamic Stochastic Constraint Optimal Power Flow methodology in order to meet the requirements of dispatching unit portfolios with different objectives at different layers of hierarchy.

Intellectual Merit: The key merit of this project is the ability of the proposed method to accommodate high in-feed of distributed resources and storage, provide a low cost solution to exponential increase in decision and grid variables and allow generation schedule dispatch with low bidding margin, including both supply and demand elasticity. This is possible by implementing massively distributed intelligent optimization architecture with coordinated hierarchical and distributed control that can interact with grid devices. This approach will allow the transmission and distribution network to operate efficiently satisfying various grid level objectives simultaneously and yet achieving global optimality conditions.

Broader Impact: The broader impact is the ability of the proposed infrastructure to transform the power grid functionalities that has substantial economic (improved grid efficiency and optimal supply and demand elasticity), societal (sustainable, reliable and resilient infrastructure) and educational value (new curriculum methods and generation and retention of next generation global workforce) which is important for developing next generation power grid.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AIS: Collaborative Research: A Novel Intelligent Grid Optimization Architecture Using Hierarchical Multi-Agent Framework for Modern Sustainable Power Grid 


The objective of this research is to develop a novel grid optimization architecture which is high-performance, distributed (low cost) and intelligent that balances supply and demand in real-time over multiple levels of the electric utility grid. The approach is to link power flow optimization routines across a three-layer hierarchy of power grid: circuits, substations, and the transmission grid with novel Approximate Dynamic Programming and Dynamic Stochastic Constraint Optimal Power Flow methods in order to meet the requirements of dispatching unit portfolios with different objectives at different layers of hierarchy.  Intellectual Merit and Broader Impact: The key merit of this proposal is the ability of the global grid optimization to integrate high penetration of dynamic sources such as renewable energy resources, electric vehicles, energy storage devices, on less proprietary basis and having a robust, sustainable and resilient next generation power grid infrastructure. This is possible through implementing approximate dynamic programming based controllers with novel massively distributed optimization architecture, for improved penetration of dynamic energy sources resources. 
This approach allows the transmission and distribution network to operate efficiently and satisfying various grid level objectives with global optimality conditions. The broader impact of this project is to seamlessly integrate significant amount of renewable energy to the electric grid network in different layers. The proposed research outcomes is being linked to educational and outreach activities to design and implement new curriculum for grid optimization, and develop and retain next generation global workforce. Thus the approach has substantial societal and economic impact and could be a potential breakthrough for developing next generation power grid.
In the course of the project, algorithms for convex optimization of the transmission and distribution system considering the renewable energy resources has been developed and implemented on IEEE standard test systems. Then an Approximate Dynamic Programming (ADP) based control architecture for distribution system and the transmission system that works as a supervisory controller and wide area controller has been developed, respectively. In the transmission system this controller is then tested as a wide area control. In the distribution system ADP controller is then tested as supervisory controller and as distributed controller for evaluating energy storage contributions. The performance analysis of the proposed method with other state-of-the-art methods are compared. It has been determined that the proposed novel architecture can balance supply and demand in real-time over multiple levels of the electric utility grid. The approach provides integrated power flow optimization routines across each layer of the grid with different objectives at each layer.
